body: **Warning** - These commits modify **unsafe code**. Please review it carefully!
cc @Gankro

FWIW, there's another possible tricks along these lines: we could store `length` and `capacity` inside the allocation, cutting off two inline words, that, allocate `{uint, uint, keys..., values..., subnodes...}` and so store 3 words instead of 5 (possibly reordered to be placed to make the alignments work more nicely).

@huonw I'm a bit worried about putting the length and capacity behind the allocation because it seems like it would be more inefficient to access/mutate them behind an extra layer of indirection. I can try it, but this seems like the same issue that made `Vec` faster than `~[]`.

A bigger win, percentage-wise, would be just to use u8's or u16's for the len/capacity. I really don't think nodes bigger than 256 elems are that reasonable to expect. 16000 or whatever is definitely silly. Of course this will require a fair amount of (totally safe) upcasting, and may require some care to avoid overflows.
@gereeter this differs to `~[]` vs. `Vec` somewhat because these allocations are never reallocated. (This can definitely be a later experiment, it does not have to be part of this PR.)

High level, this seems pretty good. Some of the implementation details are pretty dicey, though. This would benefit from some more documentation.

@huonw What's the general policy on when to use `assert` vs `debug_assert`?
@gereeter What's the status on this?
Sorry for the delay - I got distracted by other projects. I think I've fixed all the issues brought up so far.

@gereeter Great, thanks! Squashing the commit makes it hard for me to see what was actually changed, though :/

Regardless, assuming you've addressed all of our issues appropriately, this should presumably be good-to-go. I've pinged IRC for someone to officially review this (my reviews can't get anything merged). If I have time I might go over the latest version myself, but I'm inclined to leave this in the hands of an official contributor.

The beauty of the `RawTable` interface in `HashMap` is that it hides a huge percentage of the unsafe operations behind coherent safe operations. This allowed much of the "application logic" of a hashtable to be written in safe code, with the unsafe assumptions isolated behind a minimal API.

Some thought (perhaps in a follow-up patch) should be put into doing the same for BTree. I see a lot of `unsafe {}` blocks, which tends to be a rust code smell.

@cgaebel In theory, Node was intended to be BTree's RawTable. One thing I left as future work (maybe just in my head? I don't recall writing it down, now that I think about it) was passing around handles rather than raw integers for indices. Then many of the unsafes could theoretically be eliminated as the Node can trust its own handles. The exact mechanics of this were too complicated to bother with in my first-draft implementation, as I was more interested in having a solid starting point than getting it all perfect.

It should be noted that a BTree's structure is a bit more complicated than a hashtable, though.
@gereeter needs a rebase, sorry!
Rebased. Also, I wouldn't mind working on using handles instead of indices, but I'd rather base it on this work then try to put this on top of it (unless you want me to combine them into 1 PR).

If you think the handle stuff is doable, I think we'd be a lot more happy accepting such a design. I've gotta re-review this though to make sure this still makes sense.

Anyway, @huonw r? Do you have the time? You're familiar with the design of the collection, and the champion of `unsafe` stuff, and boy is this unsafe.

Except for the question of where to put the stuff copied from `HashMap` (pending on @aturon's input), I think I covered the outstanding issues. I'll hopefully get to the handle stuff soon and put it on this PR if that is desired.
For the record, I don't consider the duplication to be a blocker on landing this.

@gereeter Yeah I just didn't get a chance to go over your fixes (iirc, you squashed the commits so I couldn't see the delta). I believe you have addressed all our concerns, I just have to go over it again to be sure (that said, @huonw or whoever "officially" reviews this is the real gatekeeper, just trying to lighten their load).
I do have significantly more time now, so I'm happy to review.
@gereeter what's your status?
@gereeter Would you like someone else to take the reigns on this and finish it up?

That might be a good idea simply because I don't have enough time to have a fast response time, but this particular long pause was due to me working out and implementing a handle-based API (sorry for not responding saying so). As soon as `make check` passes, I'll push that up.
Oh, cool! :D
The handle-based API works! Also, rebased.

@gereeter Awesome! Will review hopefully this weekend.

Have you re-benched?

With the just-pushed change to unboxed closures:

```
test btree::map::bench::find_rand_100                      ... bench:         9 ns/iter (+/- 1)
test btree::map::bench::find_rand_10_000                   ... bench:         8 ns/iter (+/- 0)
test btree::map::bench::find_seq_100                       ... bench:         7 ns/iter (+/- 0)
test btree::map::bench::find_seq_10_000                    ... bench:         8 ns/iter (+/- 0)
test btree::map::bench::insert_rand_100                    ... bench:       136 ns/iter (+/- 5)
test btree::map::bench::insert_rand_10_000                 ... bench:       380 ns/iter (+/- 34)
test btree::map::bench::insert_seq_100                     ... bench:       255 ns/iter (+/- 8)
test btree::map::bench::insert_seq_10_000                  ... bench:       364 ns/iter (+/- 10)
test btree::map::bench::iter_1000                          ... bench:     19112 ns/iter (+/- 837)
test btree::map::bench::iter_100000                        ... bench:   1911961 ns/iter (+/- 33069)
test btree::map::bench::iter_20                            ... bench:       453 ns/iter (+/- 37)
```
:O those numbers seem way better! Are the "before" numbers still the same?

On master:

```
test btree::map::bench::find_rand_100                      ... bench:        35 ns/iter (+/- 2)
test btree::map::bench::find_rand_10_000                   ... bench:        88 ns/iter (+/- 3)
test btree::map::bench::find_seq_100                       ... bench:        36 ns/iter (+/- 1)
test btree::map::bench::find_seq_10_000                    ... bench:        62 ns/iter (+/- 0)
test btree::map::bench::insert_rand_100                    ... bench:       157 ns/iter (+/- 8)
test btree::map::bench::insert_rand_10_000                 ... bench:       413 ns/iter (+/- 8)
test btree::map::bench::insert_seq_100                     ... bench:       272 ns/iter (+/- 10)
test btree::map::bench::insert_seq_10_000                  ... bench:       369 ns/iter (+/- 19)
test btree::map::bench::iter_1000                          ... bench:     19049 ns/iter (+/- 740)
test btree::map::bench::iter_100000                        ... bench:   1916737 ns/iter (+/- 102250)
test btree::map::bench::iter_20                            ... bench:       424 ns/iter (+/- 40)
```

Note that this and the new numbers were tested using `check-stage1-collections` because I didn't want to wait an eternity for the whole bootstrapping process.

Just as an FYI, BTreeSet is still slower than TreeSet in this random benchmark I threw together: https://github.com/cgaebel/tree-bench . `remove` is faster, but `contains` is 25% slower and `insert` is 10% slower.
Fixed ZST destructor issue and rebased.
@gereeter still reviewing (dat diff). Please refrain from rebasing again until we've completed the review (hard to tell what changes when you rebase).
Basically at this point my only complaint is all the new rad tech needs to really be doc'd. Impl seems pretty solid, although BTree's gotten to the point that it's hard to keep it all in my head.

Docs!

Also, sorry about the rebase - I keep forgetting how annoying force pushing can be.

Awesome! Beyond minor doc nits this LGTM. I definitely want a second opinion though. There's some crazy stuff in here. r=me with doc fixes and if @huonw @cgaebel or maybe even @nikomatsakis (dat InvariantLifetime usage) also signs off on it.
Doc fixes are in.
This looks good to me. Definitely an improvement over what was there before.
Okay, fixed the doc fix typo and did @cgaebel's recommended simplification of insert.

Okay I think this is good to go! r=me with squashing, unless @huonw wants to take another crack at it.

Edit: huon does. Moar review!

Oh, since this is still on-going, one thing I'd really like to see is a more robust fuzzing of BTreeMap in the tests now that it's built on all these raw components. I know for a fact there's at least one case in the old logic that test_basic didn't cover (and I forgot to update the tests when I fixed a bug related to it during development).
Looks pretty reasonable to me, but the code is quite complicated and there's no way I can hold it all in my head especially in my current travel-addled state.

@huonw I think I've fixed all the issues you brought up.
@Gankro If you want fuzz testing, I think the ideal would be just doing a truly random sequence of operations on all the `Map` types at once, checking that they all return identical results.

@gereeter Yes, I'd like more uniform collection testing in the future. This would require either a pile of macros or collection traits, though. Anyway I don't want to block this on fuzzing. This has sat in the queue for too long!
Should I squash, or is this waiting for some more review?

YES!

Squash iiiiiit

:confetti_ball:
![](http://janeshealthykitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/butternut-squash.jpg)
Squashed!
